title: iran underground missile cities rockets strike concrete
story: Images of massive hidden bases dotted all over the Islamic republic show thousands of missiles ready for launch from the secret bunkers ready to be usedenemies make a mistake.The images come in the wake of a serious missile attack against two UK and US bases last week, with Iranian generals warning that a tsunami will sweep away all US bases.Iran has been making serious and increasingly extreme threats against the US following the January  assassination of their top general, Quasem Soleimani.Since then, Iran has put an  million bounty on Trumps head and accidentally downed a passenger plane that was leaving Tehran, killing all  on board including four Brits.Brigadier General Amir Ali Hajizadeh, commander of the Islamic Republic’s Revolutionary Guards’ aerospace ision, told reporters on Thursday that even killing Trump in revenge would not be enough.He said: “Evenwe attack every US base, kill Trump and kill his Secretary of Defense that would not be enough to avenge the blood of Hajj Qasem .”“Trump is a deserter from the Vietnam War. Who the hell is he to threaten us  He must order many coffins for his soldiers before making any threats.“Anyone can light the match but it will be us who will end the war and the losers in that war will be the Americans.”However, in spite of fiery rhetoric from both sides, things appear to be de-escalating as fears of World War  have been spiking on social media and Google all month.Hajizadeh previously broadcast footage of the largest underground base on Iranian TV.The entrance to Code , which lies in Khojir, Tehran, is hidden under a number of narrow winding roads, which run across mountainsides in the province.Hajizadeh previously said: “If enemies make a mistake, missile bases will erupt like a volcano from the depth of earth.”Pictures show the underground military base constructed with reinforced concrete and packed with rockets.Its located deep below ground — presumably designed to evade bunker-busting bombs.Iranian TV footage shows a number of missile components appearing to belong to the Qiam- ballistic missile system, which has a range of about  miles.The regime’s henchmen are then seen assembling them in one of the underground base’s launch rooms.Once fitted together, the missile is launched and is seen soaring skywards.Code  is said to be the site for the construction of Irans renowned Shahab  medium-range missiles.The Shahab, known as the Shooting Star can launch explosive chemical warheads of up to  miles, according to reports.It has been claimed Iranian officials purchased the missiles from North Korea, who constructed the weapon solely to blast the United States from the Korean Peninsula.The Lar garrison base lies in Western Iran, which also has an entrance that disappears into the mountainside, the Star on Sunday reported.NCRI sources told the newspaper it is a sprawling tunnel complex that is highly protected and secure.In a bid to maintain the tightest security, mobile phone signals are reportedly blocked off for miles surrounding it.The Queshm Missile Centre lies on the Iranian coast, understood to be hidden under around five layers of concrete.

title: schoolboy nasa intern discovers planet

title: mum 30000 lottery jackpot text just 10
story: Dawn Rivers was thrilled when she got a message with a £ sign, and assumed she had scored the jackpot prize.But the -year-old was thoroughly let down after finding out the true winning sum, after planning how to spend her windfall.A technical fault meant the text alert she got didnt show the amount she had won - which turned out to be only a tenner.Dawn, from Bourneville, Birmingham, told Birmingham Mail: Ive won £ before,its a tenner they just put a little message to say youve won £ its gone in your bank.You know when you think you have won something and your mouth dries up  Thats what happened.I was so excited to have a bit of money to play with, I had already spent it in my head.Buying some extra things for the house. Thats whats really annoyed me.The Peoples Postcode Lottery said it never made reference to a big win, and had included a link detailing the £ win in the text.A spokesman said: A spokesman for People’s Postcode Lottery said: “The winners of our biggest prizes, such as Postcode Millions or £, a day, are always contacted in person and may also be visited by a Postcode Lottery ambassador. title: 100 year old tortoise saved species 800 babies
story: Diego the super tortoise came to the rescue of his fellow creatures by mating with hundreds of partners on the Santa Cruz Island, off the coast of Calornia.However, after over  years of back-breaking work, it is time for the centurion to retire and travel home to the Galápagos Islands.The breeding programme that made his libido world famous has produced over , hatchlings, around  per cent of which call Diego their dad, according to The Galápagos National Parks service.Park director, Jorge Carrion, told AFP: He’s contributed a large percentage to the lineage that we are ing to Española.There’s a feeling of happiness to have the possibility of ing that tortoise to his natural state.He willto Española in March after a stint in quarantine.Diego was brought to San Diego Zoo in the s where he stayed as one of the zoos main attractions until , when the plight of Chelonoidis Hoodensis tortoises, which are unique to Espanola, was first recognised.Conservationists were amazed when lustful Diego got to work.The -stone, cm-long lover and another male were initially placed with twelve females, which back then was the entire remaining population of the species. title: queen landmark meeting heated atmosphere
story: To my knowledge, something like this has never happened before in terms of what it is all about and that it is happening so quickly.This is the ultimate summit between the head of state, the two heirs to the head of state and the sixth in line to the throne.With Charles and Diana’s orce, the Queen wrote to them inidually saying they had to start talking and sort orce proceedings. She didn’t meet them.Even the abdication of Edward VIII over Mrs Simpson, together below, was at Government and Church level.To have documents prepared in advance does not surprise me. The Queen has said she wants this sorted out and without delay.Many have called this an abdication and in one sense it is. Harry and Meghan expect to still have a handle on royal duty but also to lead a private le.What they mean by living financially independent, I don’t know. title: see back of harry and meghan
story: What a waste of the mountain of goodwill there was towards that happy, glamorous couple who wed on a sunshine-soaked day in Windsor in . And what a waste of their chance to play a key role in helping our Royal Family prosper after the Queen is gone.And what a waste of Harry and Meghan’s unique chance to be a living, inspirational representation of the multiracial country in which we now live. How quickly the shine has come off the golden couple.Less than two years after that wedding day, Harry and Meghan are scurrying off to an ill-defined “progressive” new le in Canada.Butthey have been unhappy with their royal roles, they have brought it on themselves. This much-loved couple have always been too thin-skinned for their own good.They have always been hysterically touchy when justied criticism came their way, such as when they lectured about climate change while reclining on private jets.The criticism was nothing personal. Hollywood stars get called out for climate hypocrisy. Do Harry and Meghan really imagine we will just tug our forelocks as they fly around the world in private jets while talking like Greta Thunberg in a tiara Harry and Meghan are never satisfied with anything less than unconditional deference. They apparently loathe royal le, yet demand to be treated like royalty.They have demonstrated an epic sense of entitlement, such as asking the taxpayer to pick up the £.million builder’s bill for doing up their home, Frogmore Cottage.Their great self-pitying delusion is that the wicked British media has it in for them. But it is not the media that caused Meghan so much excruciating embarrassment.It is largely her own dysal family and their indiscreetly flapping cakeholes, especially her dear old discarded dad Thomas Markle and her loony half-sister Samantha. Harry and Meghan’s self-pity is astounding.“Never complain, never explain,” has been the motto of the modern Royal Family. It has worked rather well.But place Harry and Meghan in front of a sympathetic camera crew, such as when ITV’s Tom Bradby trailed them on their tour of South Africa, and they can’t stop whining. Even when surrounded by victims of rape and landmines, they managed to feel sorry for themselves.“Not many people askedI’m OK,” Meghan complained in the Third World. There has not been a royal couple with such a staggering lack of self-awareness since Marie Antoinette and King Louis XVI of France. And look what happened to them.Harry and Meghan owe their mega-celebrity totally to their connection with the Royal Family. Their superstardom has nothing to do with Meghan’s acting career. Their lives of unimaginable luxury are funded in large part by the British taxpayer.The average couple spends just under £, on their wedding. Harry and Meghan were said to have blown £MILLION. Yet they do not appear to have a grateful bone between them. They seem incapable of counting their multiple blessings.Even now, after handing in their royal resignation, they give every indication that they want all the privileges of royal le with none of the obligations. They want to have their Eton mess and eat it.Harry and Meghan’s security alone currently costs around £, a year, paid for by the politan Police — which means paid for by the British taxpayer. Get the Mounties to start paying for it.And can we finally nail the great lie that Meghan has been persecuted in the UK because of her mixed race  When she first appeared, Meghan was a hurricane of fresh air. The British looked at her and it was love at first sight.This weary, ided, Brexit-battered nation was delighted to have an injection of Hollywood glamour. And millions of Brits now live in mixed-race families. There was real delight to see the Royal Family catching up with the rest of us.Among those crowds at Windsor on their wedding day I saw families of every race and creed under the sun who were ecstatic to see the Royal Family becoming less white, more inclusive, more representative.Harry and Meghan have drawn criticism because of their total lack of self-awareness. Both of them are independently rich. Harry is worth around £million after inheritances from his mother and the Queen Mum.Prince Charles gives him £million every year. Meghan made around £million from her role in long-runningTV legal drama Suits.Yet this fabulously wealthy couple have been happy to let others — the British taxpayer, Prince Charles, the Queen — pay their way in their gilded world.Six weeks, which is theof time that Harry and Meghan have just spent in Canada, is a very long time to be away from home.Unless, of course, “home” doesn’t feel like home because you feel criticised for everything you do and wear, your family – on both sides – are a nightmare and you are constantly judgedby people who have never met you and never will.I should imagine that in this case, Canada seems like a very good place to call home. So, who can blame Meghan and Harry for deciding to leave the UK behind to get away from it all, and maybe staying away from here in the long-term I have a lot of respect for the couple for ploughing their own furrow and walking their own path.Honestly, I couldn’t be happier for Harry, who has experienced so much sadness, that he has met a woman brave enough to suggest doing things a bit dferently.Although they are currently making bold statements about giving up the taxpayer-funded Sovereign Grant, they show no sign of being willing to pay for their own security, or their own flunkies, or offer the taxpayer a rebate on those reported £million nuptials.There has never been even the slightest hint of gratitude. There has never been any indication that they — this rich, pampered couple with a beautul baby boy who will never want for anything — realise how lucky they are.So Harry and Meghan are not the only ones with mixed emotions today. There is real resentment that Harry and Meghan have caused distress to our Queen and it will not be easily forgotten or forgiven.The Queen has a -year-old husband who has recently been in hospital. She has a son mired in a squalid sex scandal. And she is  years old. Who the hell do Harry and Meghan think they are This feels like an abdication with a taxpayer-funded safety net. The couple plan to “step back as senior members of the Royal Family” but show no inclination to give up the privileges and pay days that come with the job.They say they want to “work to become financially independent”. But between them they are currently worth around £million. Why not pay their own way NOW Are they really suggesting that they turn their backs on this nation while asking it to foot their bills  It looks like it. The British taxpayer will continue to stump up for their phenomenal security bills. Harry’s daddy will cough up for much .So you can’t help wondering how intelligent they really are, this TV soap actress and a man who left Eton with two A-levels— a school where my dog could get four A-levels.Do Harry and Meghan really think they have had a raw deal  Are they that stupid  There is no republican movement in this country.The Queen has reigned far too well for far too long —  years on the throne next month — for anti-monarchy sentiment to develop.The Queen has spent her entire le placing public duty above private happiness.She has been the stable, stoic centre of this nation for so long that she has single-handedly made losing our monarchy unthinkable.Yet when a spokesman for anti-monarchy pressure group Republic demanded Harry and Meghan make a clean break, I found myself nodding in agreement with every withering word.“Theyhave said that they will dip in and out of royal duties as it suits them but won’t stop taking money until they find other sources of income,” said Republic’s Graham Smith.“To suggest they’re not already financially independent is incredibly crass and belies a sense of entitlement and lack of self-awareness common among royals.”This republican is right. If Harry and Meghan want a new le hanging out with the Clooneys and striking deals with Apple, they should fund it themselves.As they say in North America, do it on your own dime. Give up the HRH titles. Stop leeching off your royal status.They will be a footnote in the story of our Royal Family, Meghan the Wallis Simpson of the st Century, Harry another Duke of Windsor who believed exile with his American orcee would make him happy.The Royal Family is not all about them.The Queen will be an impossible act to follow. But the photograph of Queen Elizabeth smiling proudly with the next three generations of future kings — Princes Charles, William and George — suggests our Royal Family will last for at least  years after Netflix has cancelled The Crown, evenone day Meghan gets to play herself.The succession is assured. Decent men will wear the crown. And Kate is great. But let history record that no royal couple was ever as adored as Harry and Meghan.It is astonishing — and unbelievably sad, perhaps even tragic — that millions of us will be happy to see the back of them.Astrological patterns repeat in families through generations, just as it is doing with Meghan and Harry.Edward VIII, who wed American orcee Wallis Simpson, put love before duty, and planted a karmic seed that is at the root of what is unfolding now. It can be likened to a virus that has been lurking in the Royal household and is now being re-activated by Harry and Meghan.So what comes next  Uranus, the planet of shock-waves, moves to confront the Sun in Aquarius on January  and forms a clash with the New Moon on the th.There is likely to be a stinging backlash as all the remaining senior family members have their roles shaken up.Meghan will create a power couple that flourishes by spring with a number of initiatives. By December , another baby announcement is likely.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: blind eye iran no longer option
story: No president could ignore the killing of US contractors, the invasion of its embassy in Baghdad, the threat to the lives of American service personnel.If that threat was imminent, he was right to act. We would have done the same to protect British servicemen and women. In fact, as Britain’s Defence Secretary I did exactly that, with the full support of Prime Minister David Cameron.Let’s not forget that every country has the right to self-defence.Of course, nobody wants this crisis to escalate. Indeed Iran’s retaliation has been noticeably limited so far.But the chorus for “de-escalation” carries risks too. Iran has been attacking Western shipping, including capturing a British tanker. Iran has fired missiles at Saudi oil refineries.Iran continues to wage proxy wars in Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. Through its militias, Iran continues to destabilise neighbouring Iraq.At some point, somebody had to draw the line. Qasem Soleimani was no hero or statesman. He directed terrorist attacks across the Middle East.Thousands of Syrians, Iraqis and Yemenis died as a result. Iranian dissidents, too, were brutally suppressed.The roadside bomb-making he sponsored killed many of our brave servicemen in Iraq. As Prime Minister Boris Johnson reminded us, he had the blood of our soldiers on his hands.Has Trump’s strike weakened the case for Western intervention  It is worth remembering our troops and those of the US are in Iraq at Iraq’s invitation.Since , we have helped lead an international coalition of more than  countries to support its fragile democracy and liberate that country from the terrorist death-cult of Daesh Isis.And thanks to precision strikes by the RAF and the training by the British Army of thousands of Iraqi troops, Daesh has lost the pernicious grip it once had.Defeating Daesh isn’t just a matter of helping a friend in need or of standing up for human rights. Mercully, we have stopped Yazidi women from being raped, prisoners being burnt alive, gay people being thrown off buildings and Western hostages sadistically executed.But tackling Daesh terrorism is also vital to protect our own way of le here in Western Europe.Islamist fundamentalism needs to be defeated, whether in Mosul, Raqqa, a Paris suburb or on London Bridge.So yes, let’s continue to work with our allies to persuade Iran’s revolutionaries to take a dferent path.Saudi Arabia, the other Gulf countries and even Russia all have roles to play in getting Iran back to the negotiating table.After the appalling shooting down of the Ukrainian airliner, let’s try to show the Iranian people their government needs to be more truthful and more open, that there is a better future beyond the mullahs and the republican guards.But diplomacy alone will not be enough. We have to protect our national interests too. Trump’s strike is a stark reminder that in the end, we must all stand up when those interests are threatened so directly.First, we must persuade other European navies to work with the US and our own Royal Navy in patrolling and protecting convoys through the Strait of Hormuz.This is a vital choke point for Europe’s trade and energy. The gas and oil we need this winter pass through it.It is ludicrous that some Nato allies won’t work with American ships for fear of upsetting the mullahs in Tehran.This has to be a US-led international operation.Second, we need a better nuclear agreement with Iran. It was right to try to halt their nuclear programme. But the previous deal wasn’t comprehensive — it didn’t even cover missiles — and it completely failed to constrain Iranian misbehaviour in the region. If anything, Iran used the access to new finance that deal released to step up its proxy wars in Yemen and where.A new deal should ensure full oversight of all Iran’s nuclear activities by the International Atomic Energy Agency, and only allow Iran back into the international markets when its civil nuclear programme is in complete compliance.Third, we have to step up our campaign against terrorism.Outside the EU after Brexit, we will still need to share intelligence and work together with our European partners to identy new attacks. But our closest ally in the battle to protect our values will always be the US. We may not always agree with Trump’s tactics but we shouldn’t ignore that he has finally cut through the illusion — Iran’s current regime is not our friend.Iran will certainly have learned a lesson from President Trump’s decisive action. But I hope we will do so too.Turning a blind eye to those who foster international terrorism is no longer an option for any of us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what you do after mistakes important
story: But in all honesty, what really matters is not so much what happened but how we respond.Take the young woman who was in court this week after drunkenly propositioning male passengers on a flight from Abu Dhabi to Manchester. She askedthey wanted to join her in the “mile-high club”, then attacked cabin crew who refused her more alcohol.Demi Burton tried to headbutt and kick six crew members and passengers who tried to restrain her before she was arrested when the plane landed.In court, the -year-old claimed she had been drinking because she has a fear of flying and said this behaviour is out of character, which may be true.Her defence lawyer Martin Callery said: “She is thoroughly ashamed of herself . . .  and utterly embarrassed at the way she behaved.”But that is certainly not the impression she conveyed outside court, where she gleefully flicked obscene hand gestures at photographers.No doubt she stopped smiling when she heard she had been sentenced to six months in prison. Personally, I’m not sure how effective prison is. But the problem with reckless behaviour is that you have to face the consequences.And I really hope for Demi, this is the moment she gets her le back on track. We all make mistakes. It’s what we do afterwards that defines us.It would be easy to assume that Demi is a hopeless case. But she is young enough to turn her le around, to work hard, do better and see this rock-bottom moment as a catalyst for change.And then something good will come from what is a very low moment in her le. We don’t have to look far for examples of people who have overcome lapses or mistakes before going on to succeed.Take Robert Downey Jr, who went from drug addict to one of Hollywood’s highest-paid actors. Or Elton John and Robbie Williams, both of whom have overcome major drug issues before enjoying renewed stardom, fatherhood and, more importantly, a good le.While it is not the same as a drunken mistake, anyone who has made it in business will have a good few failures under their belt — whether it is a dodgy commercial decision, plain bad luck or a company that has gone bust.It is not what happens to us in le but what we do next that counts. So I am guessing that, from her cell, Demi might be reflecting on what she might do dferently when she gets out. Andshe isn’t, she should be.Because it is the getting back on the horse that counts, evenit means resisting the urge to go back to bed to hide. No one is perfect. No one gets through le without messing up or things going wrong.Before success, you will get temporary defeat or total failure. The key to getting through it is resilience. And one of the best gts you can give a child is to encourage them not to give up.By the way, I speak here from experience. Like any businesswoman, I’ve made some mistakes and had my fair share of knocks.There are some that I have managed to turn to my advantage and others that I have had to chalk up to experience.The key thing is that I have learned from what went wrong, then moved on. That experience has allowed me to create a mini-manesto on how to fail how to respond to setbacks and failure, which I’ll share here now:Give yourself time to recover and reflect. Force yourself to take small steps to get back on the horse. Do not accept failure. See it as a step on the journey towards success.Remember that challenging and dficult moments are what help you grow bigger or better. Without them, you would stay the same.The only people who haven’t experienced setbacks are people who are too scared to try. So “failure” is often a sign of bravery. Hold your head up high at all times.Try your best and be proud to do so, eventhings don’t always work out the way you want them to. Remind yourself: “Where there is a will, there’s a way.” And as they say, the best thing about the future is it comes one day at a time.ANOTHER new year, another month of looking at photos of scantily clad people on beaches in sunnier climes and asking myselfI am the only person who is not on the beach.This is the time of year for massive bikini-body and holiday FOMO.But let us all take heart that it is also, oh joy, the time of year for elasticated waists hidden under chunky knitwear.Personally, I am more than happy to swap the beach for nothing to shave and no stomach to suck in. Bliss.I’M sure parents everywhere were shocked to read the story of the son who bullied his mother and stepfather so viciously he has been jailed for three years for his controlling and coercive behaviour.When Nicholas Hazell, , of County Durham, went back to live with Judith Ridley, , and her reverend husband Stephen, , after losing his job, he made their lives hell.Hazell, above, created a “horrendous atmosphere” at the family home and flew into a petulant ragehe didn’t get his own way, Durham Crown Court heard.Among his worst outbursts were when Hazell threw his mother into a chair and spat at her while holding a screwdriver to his stepfather’s throat. He also told them: “I am a master of bullying.”It sounds horric.I feel so sorry for his mum, who must be devastated that her little boy turned into a cruel bully as an adult.I dont do needles when it comes to my face.  Lasers, facials, peels . . .  sure. But needles are another story entirely.If you are willing to take the chance of injecting poison into your face, at the very least you want a predictable result. And in my experience, you don’t get it.Who wants eyebrows at the top of their head, lips that come into the room before you do, or a forehead that doesn’t move  Not me, that’s for sure. However . . .This week I read that not only is the gorgeous Abbey Clancy having micro-Botox injections, hyaluronic acid fillers and vitamins, she is doing it with TWENTY needles at once.Abbey, , is having something called an aquagold facial, so called because each needle is covered in -carat gold. The marketing blurb claims this treatment will reduce pores, blur out fine lines and leave your skin with a vibrant glow.Some might say this is a slippery slope to the stronger stuff but Abbey looks amazing.  So it has to be worth a try, don’t you think I HAD to laugh at the photos of the BBC newsreader whose dress, which had burst open minutes before going on air, was cobbled together from behind by quick-thinking colleagues.  Liz Beacon’s outfit was patched up with gaffer tape and bulldog clips.I used to believe what I saw on TV. But since filming The Apprentice, I know all too well that all is not necessarily what it seems.Two examples spring to mind. First, the countless times I have been filmed in the boardroom with a smart jacket on top and leggings or even pyjama bottoms and slippers under the boardroom table.Second, and worse, the time I somehow forgot to bring a bra on a day I was wearing a white blouse.Luckily, a kind crew member who is roughly the same size as me lent me hers.  And the show, as it always seems to do, went on.I WAS appalled to read about the private Islamic secondary school that has been “unlawfully segregating” boys and girls for all activities except weekly assemblies, according to a stinging Ofsted report.One of the teachers theretold pupils “university is not for females”, according to the report. Which begs the question of where, then, is the best place for females  The kitchen Inspectors who visited Birmingham’s Redstone Educational Academy in November last year also found male students were given privileges and treated more favourably than their female counterparts when it came to sports, school trips and work experience.That was something disputed by the headteacher.That’s not good enough. There can be no place for a school like this and it should be closed down.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

title: labours ten point plan end
story: NewsLabours ten-point plan to end anti-semitism in race challenge for new LeaderLabour leaders from the Jewish community in the UK have called for every leader candidate to sign a ten-point pledge to rid the party of vile racismShareCommentsByChris McLaughlin:,  JAN NewsSir Keir and Baroness Lawrence call for MPs to sign pledge against racism " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Anti-semitism has today been thrust to the very heart of the Labour leadership contest with a challenge for all contenders to solve the problem fast.Leaders from the Jewish community have called on every candidate to sign a ten-point pledge to rid the party of vile racism.The move came after Keir Starmer vowed to stamp out anti-semitismhe ­succeeds Jeremy Corbyn .At his campaign launch ­yesterday in Manchester – ­attended by Baroness Doreen Lawrence – he said Labour had not done enough to tackle the issue which had dogged Mr Corbyn. And he vowed: “What I would do is lead from the top and say it’s my responsibility to deal with it. I wouldn’t say it’s for ­somebody . I want the files. I want the numbers on my desk.”  Labour’s General Election campaign was derailed when Chief Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis said Mr Corbyn was unfit for high office because of anti-Semitism and that a victory for Labour would put the “very soul of our nation” at stake.In its statement today, the Board of Deputies of British Jews calls on all ­contenders to sign up to its ten-point plan. It includes settling all outstanding anti-Semitism cases by a fixed deadline. Mr Corbyn’s aides have been ­accused of interfering in cases against members facing claims of anti-Semitism.  The Deputies say the new leader must ensure the ­internal disciplinary process is “independent”. They also call for awareness ­programmes. Prosecutors are considering charges against five people in the party over anti-Semitism. The issue re-emerged ahead of the close of nominations for the leader and deputy leader tomorrow.

title: lisa nandy councils must power
story: NewsopinionLisa Nandy: Councils must have the power to run bus services for people, not profitsLeadership hopeful Lisa Nandy says decade of austerity has forced cuts in bus services - but Labour councils like Nottingham have produced very successful long-term plans for public transport networksShareCommentsByLisa Nandy:,  JAN NewsopinionLisa Nandy said she will be the Labour leader who speaks up for people, places and problems that for too long Westminster has ignored " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn the House of Commons  months ago Jeremy Corbyn challenged Theresa May about the shocking state of Britain’s buses. He was mocked by Tory MPs and commentators but back at my home in Wigan people cheered him on. It showed a political system that is staggeringly out of touch with the things that matter. Nearly % of all public transport journeys are made by bus. In many parts of the country buses are the only public transport there is. But to listen to the Tories you’d think they don’t even exist. We pay too much for shockingly bad buses. Fares have gone up by a whopping % in a decade. And around , routes have been cancelled in that time. This week I had an email from a - year-old asking why the bus she needs to get to her nan’s house has been cancelled. She wrote: “Over the past few years I have had a lot to go through and going to my nan’s house has really boosted my confidence.” Now she can’t get there. Labour talked a lot about our rail policies at the last election but we should have been shouting louder about buses. A decade of austerity has forced cuts in bus services upon councils. This must end. Labour councils like Nottingham have produced very successful long-term plans for their bus network. All councils should have the power to take control of bus services so they set the fares and the routes.

title: autistic man 21 says mucking
story: Horsforth, near his home in Leeds" to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. The -year-old, who has autism and a learning disability, was delighted to land the role after finding it impossible to even find a volunteer position. But he hasn’t looked back since joining Mencap’s supported employment programme two years ago. Mitch, who mucks out the pigs twice a day, come rain or shine, said: “It’s a dream job. It means the world to me to do a job I truly enjoy.” Mitch studied Animal Management at college, which led to a work placement as a farmhand at None Go Bye Farm in Horsforth, near his home in Leeds. This became a proper paid job after Mitch more than proved his worth. Fewer than five per cent of people with a learning disability have paid employment in the UK, yet more than  per cent want to work. Mitch said: “Some people just won’t hire people with disabilities – a shame, considering we’re in the st century.“Working on the farm has been an important part of my le and has helped me gain confidence in a lot of ways,especially talking to people. I really love working with the animals and my dferent jobs on the farm.”Rosie, Mitch’s manager at None Go Bye Farm, said: “Mitch works really hard to do his best, and his passion and enthusiasm for animals is always very clear.”

title: backpackers left clinging life car
story: NewsBrit backpackers left clinging to le as car flipped onto roof in Australian outbackBest friends Robyn Jago, , and Elyse O’Donnell, from Merseyside, are recovering from their horror injuries after the terrying car crash while on their dream tripShareCommentsByCharlotte Hadfield:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsBest friends Robyn Jago and Elyse O’Donnell " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo backpackers were left clinging to le after their car lost control and flipped onto its roof in a remote spot in the middle of the Australian outback. Best friends Robyn Jago, , and Elyse O’Donnell, from Merseyside, have described their terrying experience while on a dream trip. Their adventure took a devastating turn when a tyre on the car they were travelling in burst, causing it to lose control and veer off in the wrong direction, the Liverpool Echo reports. Elyse, who was driving the car at the time, tried to regain control but it soon hit a dip at the side of the road causing it to flip onto its roof and hit a nearby tree, which smashed straight through the windscreen. They escaped the car with severe injuries, including broken backs, and the emergency services were four hours away. Robyn from Halewood, and Elyse, from Stockbridge Village, travelled over to Perth together from Thailand, back in February . After securing jobs on a farm, the pair spent the following year working “in the middle of nowhere” in Broome and Hallscreek, in order to save up enough money to travel up the East coast. But on September , their trip took a devastating turn. Robyn said she first realised that something was wrong, when she smelt “burning rubber” coming from the tyres - but it was already too late. Ironically, Australian police told Robynshe had not had removed her seat-belt she would have been impaled by the tree.  Robyn told the Echo: “I woke up and I was on my hands and knees scrunched up in a ball. I donapost remember being in the air flipping. I just remember seeing a tiny glimpse out of the window which I knew wasnapost the road. I was trying to understand what had happened when I saw a light switch on the floor next to me and thataposs when I realised that it was actually the roof of the car and that we were upside down. Robyn and Elyse were in the car with two other women, who they had met the month before, but who have asked not to be named.  Seconds before the accident, Robyn had unfastened her seat belt in order to change position in the tightly packed car, meaning she took the full force of the crash. Robyn said: Your senses slowly start coming back to you and I heard screaming and Elyseaposs voice. “She had managed to get out of the car by this point withand they were stood on the side of the road. When I looked to my right I sawcovered in blood, I thought she was dead. She had blood all over her face and wounds where the tree had scraped her. I screamed.” Robyn said: “Elyse could hear a hissing noise coming from the car so she thought it was going to blow. “She was shouting ‘you need to get out of the car.”  By this point, Robyn said she knew she had broken her back but they had no other option but to get out of the car. She said: “I couldn’t get out of the side I was on so we had to get out of the other side but there was a branch coming through the window. “Elyse andhad to pull us both out in the end.” Robyn suffered from a bleed on the brain during the crash and was left with a broken back and a burst finger. Elyse broke her back and neck in five dferent places.  One of the other two women who was travelling in the car at the time of the crash sustained a total of  serious injuries including a wound to the head, while the other was left with black eye and a torn ligament to the shoulder. Robyn said: “I never take my seatbelt off, I literally just took it off for a minute to get comfortable. “But the police told me afterwards thatI had had my seat belt on there was a good chance I would have been impaled by the tree and would probably have been dead by now.” After managing to escape from the vehicle, the girls stood “shaking” as they tried to work out what to do next. Robyn said the crash took place literally in the middle of nowhere” and was a three and a half hour drive away from the nearest hospital. However, thanks to a lorry driver who was driving past shortly after the accident, the girls managed to get to the roadside to call for help. Robyn said: “We were far away from the road because of where the car landed butheard a lorry going past so she bombed it up to the side of the road.  She told him aposweaposve just been in a car crash’ and he grabbed his first aid kit, he was lovely.” There was a mining site not too far away so he called there and said ‘have you got first aiders to help in any way they can. Robyn said it took a total of four hours for an ambulance and police to arrive at the scene of the crash. The girls were then taken to the nearest clinic,  minutes away, to be assessed before Robyn was taken with one of the other women, by air ambulance to Broome Hospital. While Elyse and her other friend who was involved in the crash, were taken to Kunnuara Hospital the following day. Robyn said: “The first person Elyse told was her mum. She panicked at first because all Elyse did was cry down the phone but then once she told her everyone’s alive and she went really calm and calmed Elyse right down. “Elyse told my sister for me because I lost my phone in the crash. It was so surreal it honestly still doesn’t feel like it happened to us.”  Robyn spent the following eight days after the accident being treated in hospital before she was discharged over the course of a week, while Elyse spent the following nine days in hospital. Due to the severity of both of their injuries, they were fitted with neck braces and had to attend hospital appointments several times a week for the following three months. Robyn said: We were both in absolute agony. After we were discharged from hospital we spent the next three months mostly indoors at our friendaposs house. I had to go back to the hospital for constant checks. I was put on medication for my brain haemorrhage and memory games and brain training. We could walk but we spent a lot of time lying down because of the pain. We were tired all the time, we just had no energy. Since the accident, Robyn and Elyse have made a good progress with their injuries and had their back braces removed in December. Despite being able to walk now unsupported, Robyn said they are both unable toto work until at least March and suffer from a lot of pain which makes it a nightmare to sleep at night. Robyn said the psychological pain of the accident, has also been unbearable with both Elyse and herself regularly suffering from flash backs and night terrors. But due to the high cost of receiving physiotherapy for their injuries and counselling, the girls have been unable to get the help they desperately need. Robyn said: Itaposs taken a toll on our mental health. Iaposve had depression and anxiety before but itaposs been a whole new level since the accident. Weaposve had to sit indoors for three months watching our savings disappear while we recover. Weaposve both struggled to sleep since. We have sleep paralysis and suffer from nightly flashbacks. She added: Weaposre so scared of travelling in cars now. Weaposll be in a taxi and itaposll change lanes and we both get so nervous. Weaposre just very nervous about everything little thing. The doctor has told us weaposre not allowed to go back to work until March.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA boy who was kicked out of school at the age of just five is still not allowed tofour months later. Last September, just two days into the new school year , Rudi Barnes was permanently excluded from St Malachyaposs RC Primary in Miles Platting, Manchester. Headteacher Mrs Janine Parker took the decision after an incident in which he kicked and punched teaching staff, tipped over chairs and a table, and pulled displays off a wall. It was the culmination of a pattern of violent behaviour that began in nursery when he was just three. He hasnapost had another day in school since his exclusion, the Manchester Evening News reports. The week before Christmas, little Rudi was writing out cards for all his classmates. His parents Claire Scae and Carl Barnes had to take them in to school for him, but they fear Rudi is already being left behind. He went to a friendaposs birthday party and this kid said aposnobody remembers you in school apos, said Claire, . He got really upset, itaposs heartbreaking. While the parents understand why the school made the drastic decision, they are distraught and believe more should have been done to keep him in school and get him the help he clearly needs. The couple say they have no idea where Rudiaposs behaviour comes from and that it doesnapost happen at home.  Certainly, Rudiaposs exclusion is unusual. There were just  children permanently excluded aged five across the country in -, according to the Department for Education. In Manchester, only thirteen pupils in total were permanently excluded from state-funded primary schools. The advice to headteachers is that it should be an absolute last resort. However,  as the M.E.N has reported previously  , soaring rates of exclusions has been a serious problem in Manchester schools in recent years. A government review, led by former childrenaposs minister Edward Timpson and published last year, pointed to an array of negative outcomes for children who are excluded including a reduced likelihood of achieving good GCSEs, a higher chance of ending up unemployed and a higher chance of being either the victim, or perpetrator of a crime. In November , Manchester Council responded by launching a new aposInclusion Strategyapos that was designed to tackle exclusion rates. But the sad story of how Rudi Barnes came to be kicked out of school at such a young age, and his parentsapos ongoing battle to make sure he gets an education, highlights how this continues to be a challenging problem.Many of those tasked with preventing exclusions, from school staff to mental health services, are struggling with a rapidly increasing workload and dwindling budgets after a decade of government funding cuts. Four months after his permanent exclusion, Rudi still hasnapost had another day at school or been assessed by a mental health professional, despite being referred to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Servicesat least nine times, the M.E.N understands. By law, the local authority must make arrangements for a childaposs full time education from the sixth day of exclusion onwards. Rudi has been offered alternative provision at Bridgelea, a Pupil Referral Unit , for permanently excluded children but it has left the parents in a quandry. There used to be a Bridgelea site in Gorton, near to their home in Miles Platting, but that closed in . The main PRU site is in Withington, almost six miles away and several bus journeys away for Claire and Carl who do not have a car and are reliant on state benefits. Carl, , is a full-time carer to partner Claire who has diabetes, and is also responsible for getting Rudiaposs nine-year-old brother and two-year-old sister to school every day. The family borrowed a car to take Rudi for a day visit to Bridgelea and after meeting the headteacher, they believe the school can provide the support he needs. But the couple feel it is simply aposimpossibleapos for Carl to get the other children to school and also take Rudi to Bridgelea.  Carl and Claire were hoping Rudi could get funding from the council for transport from home to school but so far none has materialised. Manchester Council says Rudi has been provided with a bus pass for free travel and ultimately, there is no excuse for him not to be at Bridgelea. The authority has now threatened to prosecute Carl and Claire for failing to send their child to school, although it has agreed to pause proceedings after the M.E.N requested a comment about the case. If convicted, the couple face a fine or even a prison sentence. They said they will take me to court, said Carl. Fine,thataposs what it takes to explain it all, we will go to court. It seems extreme that Rudiaposs future should now be decided in a criminal court room. Carl and Claire struggle to understand how it got to this point. Speaking at the familyaposs neatly-kept home last week, the couple showed the M.E.N a pile of paper documents relating to Rudiaposs problems at school. It has already been a long and intimidating process. Rudiaposs violent behaviour began just months after he first started in nursery at St Malachyaposs in September . As might be expected of such a young child, many of the incidents were petulant in nature. They offered him a pear, and he doesnapost like pears, said Carl. So he threw it at the teacher and cut her lip. He was excluded from reception for that. Staff tried to handle Rudiaposs outbursts by taking him out of the room, but by reception, his behaviour was escalating. They said he was just getting more angry, said Carl They did get a psychologist in, a behaviour specialist. But they only came one day and didnapost see anything. The teacher told us theyaposre trained in holding techniques but they donapost like using it. If theyaposd have held him until he calmed down, then he gives hugs and kisses out to the teachers. If theyaposd held him, he wouldnapost have got excluded, or he would have got the help earlier on.  In response to Claire and Carlaposs claims, a spokesperson for the Diocese of Salford, the organisation that runs St Malchyaposs said: It would not be appropriate to comment on the inidual circumstances of any one pupil . At St Malachyaposs all decisions are taken in the best interest of our school community. However, it is understood the schoolaposs position is that only aposselectedapos, more senior staff are trained in holding techniques and that other de-escalation techniques were used with Rudi following advice from an external behaviour consultant. Often, Rudi doesnapost appear to even remember what has happened after a violent episode at school and will be hugging the same teachers he was hitting only minutes earlier. Claire and Carl describe their son as a aposlovingapos little boy who likes giving out hugs so much he even embraces the staff at his local ASDA.  Rudi has both younger and older siblings and doesnapost seem to suffer the same rage blackouts with them or his parents.  I said to one of the teachers aposis it really that bad apos said Claire.   So she showed me a video of it on the iPad and I couldnapost believe it. I thought aposis that really Rudi apos thataposs not my son. He was in a rage, his face looked dferent and everything I thought aposoh my godapos. I was heartbroken.   Itaposs like he sees red and doesnapost know what heaposs doing, but I donapost know what triggers it off.   This is what we want to find out - weaposve been begging for help. Over the past eighteen months, Rudiaposs parents, his GP and staff at St Malachyaposs have all referred him to Child and Adolescent Mental Health Serviceson several occasions. But CAMHS repeatedly refused to see Rudi on the basis he did not aposfit the criteriaapos. Carl and Claire say they were told in person they would have to wait until he was six before he would be seen. That appears to be true as CAMHS offered an appointment three days after Rudi turned six in December. But while they are happy to finally see a step forward, Carl and Claire fear it will still be a y process before Rudi gets the help he needs. And they believeRudi had been seen earlier, he might not have ended up being permanently excluded in the first place.  Heaposs heartbroken he canapost go to school, but itaposs just aposhard luck, nobodyaposs going to even look at you yetapos, said Claire. We shouldnapost be in this predicament, it should all be in place before the child is permanently excluded. He should have been sent to the PRU while he was at school. Weaposve looked into finding him another one nearer us but there isnapost one. I went in [to CAMHS] crying saying aposplease help me, what have I got to do apos, they said heaposs got to be six. Meanwhile, with Rudi now having been out of school for more than four months, the effects are starting to show. His preference is to be at St Malachyaposs and his absence is made all the more painful as he often accompanies his dad when dropping off and picking up his older brother. Mum Claire says Rudi now often refuses to eat or hides food around the house at meal times. The teacher hugged him the other day and said aposRudi youaposve lost weightapos, said Claire. Itaposs shocking. At dinner, he was crying, aposIaposm not eating it, Iaposm not eating itapos. He goes to pick his brother up and heaposs crying saying aposwhy canapost I go to school apos Heaposs only a baby - he doesnapost know whataposs happened. He says aposIaposm missing my friendsapos. Heaposs missing out on a lot. Claire and Carl are aware that some people might write them off as bad parents because of Rudiaposs predicament. But they say they couldnapost be trying any harder to do whataposs best for him and get him back in school. We just feel like weaposre hitting our heads off a wall, said Claire. The doctor said, aposyouaposve hit a brick wall, thereaposs no help out there for that age groupapos.  Imagine we were those parents who donapost caretheir kids go to school  Our kids donapost get a day off. We make sure they get up in the morning, theyaposre not even late.  It seems like itaposs all down to money though, nobody wants to help you, you get told aposphone this person, phone that personapos, weaposve phoned that many people weaposre going round in circles. Manchester Council funds aposhome to schoolapos transport services via the Travel Co-Ordination Unit. It is a complicated process that usually involves a child already having a statement of Special Educational Needsor Education, Health and Careplan. Rudi has neither because he has yet to be assessed by a professional. But evenhe does get an SEN statement, his parents may struggle to get travel support getting him to school. In its - budget, the council said there are aposexisting budget pressuresapos totalling £.million aposrelating to Special Education Needs and Disabilityhome to school transport, leaving care accommodation and adoption allowances. As a result, the council intends to save £, from its Travel Co-Ordination budget between -. However, the M.E.N understands efforts are now being made to try and resolve the situation with Rudiaposs travel arrangements. He is also due to have his first appointment with the CAMHS service in the next few days. But Claire and Carl still have a long way to go with getting Rudi back in full-time education and receiving the help he needs. There must be other kids going through this, said Carl. I think it should be highlighted that no matter what age you are,you need help, you need help. Not just my kids, all the other kids out there. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA boy who became paralysed ­within hours of his birth because of a brain and spinal cord bleed has ­defied odds by stepping into . Parents Mark and India Aldridge were devastated when doctors told them newborn Ralph would never sit, stand, crawl or walk. Now thanks to pioneering specialist physio Ralph, aged two, can keep up with his twin brother Wilbur, attend nursery and feel his proud parents tickling his feet. India said: “To see him shouting ‘Me walk, me walk’ makes my heart melt with joy.” The couple’s world fell apart eight hours after the twins’ birth in December  when Ralph was rushed to hospital with a brain haemorrhage and put into a coma. India, , said: “He was completely floppy, like a rag doll, and head to toe in bruises.” Two weeks later he was scanned at St George’s Hospital in Tooting, South London. The parents were told Ralph would never move below his waist. His hips were also out of alignment, with his feet twisted backwards. The wait for NHS physio was up to three months. India said: “It was hopeless and we felt powerless.”  They were paying for weekly private physio at their home but in April  saw a TV news item about Neurokinex Kids, a new rehab facility for children with a spinal cord injury in Crawley, West Sussex,  miles from their South London home in New Malden. Ralph was referred for six free NHS sessions, which he started that May . India said: “A weight was lted from our shoulders. The equipment and expertise was mind-blowing and the sense of positivity gave us hope for the first time since the birth.”  Specialist physios encouraged Ralph to play games to develop his core, his leg strength and the ­alignment from his hips to his feet through activities such as throwing balls into hoops and soft-play facilities. With intensive training he simulated walking on a ­treadmill supported by a ­harness while electrical stimulation therapy ­activated his nerve paths.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA daredevil jailed for three months after ­scaling the Shard says it was worth every second – despite witnessing daily horrors behind bars. George King, , shared a cell with violent criminals and saw a string of stabbings and other attacks. But as he left Pentonville Prison in North London, he told the Sunday Mirror he has no regrets about climbing the ,ft Shard which towers over the capital. George, a free solo climber, said: “My biggest fear in le is regret. We all die, but not everyone lives le before.” Of his time behind bars, he said: “I had seven cell-mates – drug dealers and gang members. “I saw stabbings on most days. I saw somebody get kettled, when boiling water was thrown over them. “Kids were self-harming every day with razor blades.” George, from Oxford, only ended up in a men’s jail because Feltham Young Offenders Institution was full. He was  when jailed in October after the Shard’s owners brought a civil case against him for breaching an injunction against “persons unknown” entering the building. Although police were waiting for George at the top they merely escorted him off the premises and took no further action.  George and his parents believe he should have got community service rather than being jailed at huge taxpayer expense. Guidance says civil prisoners should be kept apart from convicted criminals – yet George found himself among seasoned offenders. Responding to critics who say his actions, which saw London Bridge station closed briefly, were dangerous, he said: “The police officers who met me at the top said it made their week.  “People go out drinking every weekend and cause violence, they’re the ones who put a strain on the emergency services. I want to inspire people to conquer their goals, follow their passions.” He prepared for his Shard assent by tackling the world’s largest climbing wall, in the Netherlands, and scaling hundreds of cranes, including one near Wembley Stadium. He said of his Shard escapade last July: “It wasn’t about the attention, it was the thrill of getting to the top.”  His mum Hilary, , who works in property, criticised the decision to jail him. She said: “For five weeks he didn’t have a change of clothes. He wasn’t even supposed to be in there. “I spoke to the prison chaplain and he said George should never have been on that wing – he was sent down for breaching an injunction, not for a criminal conviction. I have barely slept for three months.” Hilary has no plans to stop him from pursuing his passions, adding: “He’s so determined, I don’t think we could ever stop him. I’d rather he didn’t, but he knows what he’s doing and he’s very good at it.”George’s chartered surveyor dad Clive, , added: “For so long we didn’t know what he was up to. “We had an inkling when a grappling hook turned up in the post, but we never anticipated this.” George, who plans to publish a book and venture into bare-knuckle boxing and BASE jumping, fell foul of an injunction taken out to halt a class equality protest at the Shard in .

title: couple buys dump house council
story: NewsCouple buys dump house from council for £ and turn it into £, homeEXCLUSIVE: Debbie and Ste Hodges hard work paid off as their blood and guts has transformed their Liverpool home into a valuable asset for just £,ShareCommentsByEmily Hall:,  JAN NewsDebbie and Ste Hodge and their home on Garrick Street in Liverpool which they bought for just £ " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDelighted Debbie and Ste Hodge are finally quids in after buying a house for a pound and turning it into a £, asset. They put “blood, sweat and tears” into the two-bed dump, bought under a council regeneration scheme. Debbie and Ste were shaken when they first stepped through the door – armed with a £, schedule of works from Liverpool City Council to bring it up to scratch. The th century terraced house had been hit by fire and had crumbling walls, broken bricks and burnt joists. But the couple worked -, did most of the renovations themselves and in  months transformed it into a cosy home for just £,. After enjoying their first Christmas in the double-fronted home in the city’s Wavertree district, the pair have been buoyed by a valuation of £,. Debbie, , says: “We never want to move because we have put so much of ourselves into this house. People thought we were nuts. “We’ve crawled on the floors, we built the floors… it’s a gamble we took and we love it. Our blood and guts have gone into it. If they’d give us next door, we’d do it again!” Recalling the first time she saw the property, Debbie says: “It was just a shell. All the joists were burnt. It was terrible. “Honestly, it was just stacks and stacks of bricks. There was nothing. My family were saying to me, ‘You’re mad’.”  Every floor had to be replaced, chimneys were removed, the sinking kitchen was underpinned, all fittings were ripped out and the windows were upgraded. Debbie and Ste, , used their savings and took a small loan to complete the work – and it was hard graft. We were there until midnight with torches. We went seven days a week, we didn’t miss a day,” Debbie says. She scoured local ads for bargains and bagged a £, kitchen for a tenth of the price and a £, bathroom suite for £,. They also picked up a slightly damaged £, front door for £.  And, slowly but surely, the place came together. Now it is a shining example of how Liverpool is breathing new le into former slums. The council unveiled its Homes For A Pound scheme in . A year later, bosses vowed that , empty houses would be brought back into use. Since then, , homes have been reoccupied – including  in the Webster Triangle, Wavertree, where the Hodges live. Seven more families are due to move in soon. A similar scheme has since been launched in Stoke-on-Trent. Last year, a Channel  documentary about the renovations in Liverpool featured Debbie and Ste.  The couple say the sense of community in the Webster Triangle is a great example of how councils candepressed areas to homely neighbourhoods. The Hodges used to rent in Anfield and had struggled to get a mortgage. Debbie suffered a serious long-term illness and Ste’s wages as a carpet cleaner were not enough to secure a home loan. Debbie says: “The council scheme was the best thing to happen to us. It brings communities together. When we moved in, there were only about three houses in the road occupied. But it’s moving on now, it’s coming to be more of a community and about half the street is filled.  “We’ve met all the neighbours and introduced ourselves. People come from everywhere, dferent areas, dferent countries. It’s a lovely community and I’m really settled here. I just love it. Once a month we clean the street and make it nice. The area is coming up, there are bars and restaurants opening further down the road… I just wouldn’t move. “I can definitely see the area getting better and we’ve never been so happy.” The couple have two daughters – Jade, , a psychologist who has her own home, and -year-old teaching assistant Jenna, who still lives with her parents and is studying for an MSC. Debbie hopes the Homes For A Pound scheme will help young Liverpudlians like Jenna get on the property ladder.

story: NewsCouple claim £, Jamaica TUI holiday was hell on earth where guests snorted cokeKarl Lewis-law, , and we Caroline, , claimed they saw guests at the Grand Palladium Lady Hamilton Resort  Spa "snorting coke" from tablesShareCommentsByJohn Glover:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsKarl Lewis-law, , was celebrating his th wedding anniversary with his we Caroline,  " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA couple have slammed TUI for selling a apossub-parapos luxurious hotel and claimed guests were snorting coke from tables. Karl Lewis-law, , spent £, on his visit to hell on earth to Jamaica to celebrate his th wedding anniversary with his we Caroline, , for nearly a month. The professional caterers from Canterbury, Kent say they were shocked when they saw staff members in public selling drugs and guests snorting cocaine on tables in front of children. TUI say there have been no complaints of similar activity at the resort. The couple were staying from November  to December  at the five-star platinum Ti rated hotel Grand Palladium Lady Hamilton Resort  Spa in Lucea near Montego Bay, Jamaica. Complaints on TripAdvisor dating nine months ago have also claimed staff are selling drugs to guests, however the majority of reviews are positive. aposThreestixapos wrote in April  that his friend was offered drugs on the beaches while they were staying there. Maggie Muck said in February  the only negative was: If you are a young guy or a girl, you will definitely be asked by literally every local resort workeryou want weed. Just a heads up, my boyfriend was getting annoyed by how many people asked him.  Karl wrote on TUIaposs Facebook page sharing pictures on January  saying: This hotel is no more than a two star rating and certainly Not  star Platinum. With evidence of faulty electrics throughout the property, debris and broken glass on the beaches, cockroach infestation, substandard and too often times of inedible food, coupled with public displays of drug dealing on a daily basis. Even staff members were drunk on duty and a member of staff being stretchered away to an ambulance following a drunken fall, in full public gaze. The images show raw meat given to the customers for one of the meals, broken chairs and roofs appearing to fall apart with live cables exposed on the grass or from above.  Karl said: With regards to our visit to hell on earth. On arrival to the hotel we suffered daily power cuts that could last anything from two minutes to an hour and they would happen daily at least four or five times a day. We endured two and three hour queues for food and restaurants again on a daily basis, when you did get to eat there would be no crockery on the tables, no cutlery on the tables, so you couldnapost even eat when you got into a restaurant. The food in the restaurants was nothing short of disgraceful. We are unhappy about the fact that there was at least four incidents of people either breaking bones or seriously injuring themselves.  One member of staff fell from a balcony and hit a storm drain, the resulting injury was nothing short of horrendous with his head and face split wide open for all to see, not something you would expect on your five star premium holiday experience. We are particularly upset about live and exposed electrics hanging from ceilings or lying in soaking wet grass that could easily either seriously injure someone who may either step on it or even worse a child touches one. It would be all over for them. Karl also said he spotted staff members openly selling drugs around children.  He added: Staff walking around openly selling drugs, guests snorting coke off the tables in full view of families and children, and when customers complain you absolve yourselves [TUI] of any responsibility. Dealing goes on, on the beaches. A staff member fell off the top balcony of our accommodation block, customer injuries happened on walkways and stairs during the rain, ideally as the floors are marble. They have mats and signs to tell guests that the floors are wet and slippery, however these are always too late to be put out and guests hurt themselves.  Two broken legs and two sprained or injured wrists and forearms. I think one of the guests even walked into a sharp splinter that stabbed her in the stomach, it pierced the skin but she said she was fine. The Jamaican government decriminalised drugs in  making the possession of around . grams a petty offence and no longer a criminal offence as long as it is used for medicinal, scientic, religious and medical purposes. It paved way for a licensing authority to be set-up to deal with regulations and cultivation of marijuana for scientic, therapeutic and medical purposes. It also allowed Rastafarians to legally use it for the first time on the island for religious purposes.

It remains to be seen who will secure the lucrative interview with the couple. In a short statement, a media representative for CBS claimed Gayle King had not been in discussions with Meghan and Harry, or their representatives, about doing an interview at this point in time. Since the Duke and Duchess made their shock announcement, Meghan has fled to Canada to rejoin her son, Archie, eight months. Meanwhile, Harry is said to be locked in talks with the Queen, Prince Charles and Prince William, as staff at Buckingham Palace work out how to coordinate the new roles Harry and Meghan want to take on.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe last few years have been dominated by Brexit but now the Great British Public has a new royal exit to fret over - Megxit. The Duke and Duchess of Sussex made a shock announcement on Wednesday that they would be stepping back from senior royal duties and carve out a progressive new role. The couple want to achieve financial independence and will now split their time between the UK and North America. The Queen was said to be disappointed by the news with Buckingham Palace saying these were complicated issues which needed to be worked through. Will they keep their royal titles, what will the new role involve and how do the couple plan to make money  Hereaposs what we know...What is aposMegxitapos  After spending the Christmas holidays in Canada, on Wednesday a statement was posted on the Sussexaposs Instagram announcing they wish to step back as senior members of the Royal Family and become financially independent. The couple said they will continue to fully support the Queen, the Commonwealth, and their patronages but also focus on the launch of their new charitable entity.  Was the Queen told beforehand  After the news broke the Queen was said to be disappointed by the bombshell announcement. A statement from Buckingham Palace released shortly after said: Discussions with The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are at an early stage. We understand their desire to take a dferent approach, but these are complicated issues that will take time to work through. On Thursday, January , the Queen led an emergency four-way call from Sandringham, with Prince Charles dialling in from Scotland and Princes William and Harry in London.  Why do they want to step back  The couple may have been planning to step back for months with a royal source saying it all stems from their tour in South Africa. The source said Harry saw Meghan was struggling and told her he did not want to do another tour with the press and said they would go their own way. Meghan admitted royal le had been hard and she had not been prepared for the intensity of the media scrutiny in an ITV documentary filmed during their tour. Prince Harry was also asked about his brother Prince William during the documentary, following reports the brothers had fallen out. He said the pair were on dferent paths but he loved him dearly and the the majority of stuff was created out of nothing. The couple broke away from the Royal Foundation charity they shared with Prince William and Kate last year.  Where will Harry and Meghan live now  The couple said they will split their time between the UK and North America. In a statement released on their new website, Prince Harry and Meghan said they would continue to use Frogmore Cottage as their official residence but only with the Queenaposs permission. The couple spent £.m refurbishing the royal residence last year. Renovations were funded through the Sovereign Grant - a sum of money given to the Monarch from the Government annually which is made up of Crown Estate profits. Expenses relating to fixtures, furnishings and fittings were funded privately by the couple. Although the couple have not said where they will live in North America, many believe Canada is their preferred option. Meghan lived in Toronto for years while working on seven series of US legal drama Suits and has many friends in the city, which she is said to consider her home. The couple spent Christmas in Vancouver and Meghan has now flown back there to be with baby Archie.  How will they become financially independent and what will it cost  The couple said they value the ability to earn a professional income which they are currently prohibited from doing. It is thought once they become financially autonomous they will make money by expanding their charitable work and striking commercial deals under the Royal Sussex brand. The couple made an application to trademark Sussex Royal last year. Prince Harryaposs fortune is thought to stand around £m, much of which he inherited from his mother Princess Diana and the Queen Mother. Meghan is said to have brought an estimated £m to their marriage. The couple currently receive five per cent of their funding from the Sovereign Grant. The other  per cent is from the income received by Prince Charles, generated by the Duchy of Cornwall. Prince Harry and Meghan will no longer receive the Sovereign Grant but said they hope to still receive money from Prince Charles. Prince Harry and Meghan said they will continue to have publicly-funded security by The politan Police which is mandated by the Home Office. The Government refuses to break down the cost of security, although it is estimated to add up to £m. It is unclear who will fund security for the couple in North America, it may be funded by taxpayers apos or privately. The couple have already said all their private travel is paid for privately and not by UK taxpayers.  However all overseas visits are paid for by the Sovereign Grant and contributions from host countries. The Queen may also decide to charge the couple rent for Frogmore Cottage. This could be as much as £, per year.  Will they lose their titles  The couple suggest on their website they will be able to keep their titles, citing historic precedent and Prince Harry will remain sixth in line to the throne. Princess Beatrice and Eugenie both have jobs and hold titles.  What does this mean for Archie  The couple ed from their festive break in Canada earlier this week, but left baby Archie in Canada with his nanny. After the announcement Meghan ed to Canada. On their website the couple said they plan to raise Archie with an appreciation for the royal tradition into which he was born. Splitting time between the UK and US may mean Archie is not able to attend the schools traditional to the Royal Family. Canada has more than  independent schools but the couple will not have to make a decision on his schooling for at least a couple more years.
